Award.AwardTitle: Maximizing Science Output of LIGO: Improved Detectors and Data Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a research project in support of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory (LIGO), aimed at maximizing its scientific output, by the formulation of strategies for improving LIGO detectors and the development and implementation of new ways to analyze LIGO data. This project will: (i) contribute to the advancement of precision measurement technology, (ii) allow LIGO to deepen our understanding of general relativity, and (iii) push the frontier of experimental physics at the interface between gravitational and quantum physics. This project will be carried out by the Caltech Relativity Theory (CaRT) group and will serve as a training ground for young physicists and astrophysicists, by teaching them a wide variety of research techniques. Members of the CaRT will also pursue a wide range of activities that reach out to the broader scientific community and the general public.

More specifically, this project will consists of four directions. (A) It will formulate and evaluate innovative approaches to improving LIGO's sensitivity, by studying how Advanced LIGO detectors should be upgraded, and by inventing new quantum metrology techniques for use in future detectors. The program will also explore new approaches to gravitational wave (GW) detection, and explore the quantum behavior of human-sized objects, and search for new physics for macroscopic objects in the quantum regime. (B) Numerical relativity binary black hole simulations from the Spectral Einstein Code (SpEC) will be used for LIGO data analysis: (i) Simulations following up on LIGO detections will be used to verify the accuracy of phenomenological waveform models, to explore parameter biases of these models, and to perform alternative parameter estimation strategies as needed; and (ii) Surrogate waveform models, which interpolate between numerical relativity waveforms to produce a waveform at requested parameters to high accuracy, will be implemented into LAL and be used in parameter estimation studies on GW150914, GW151226, and future events. (C) More efficient search algorithms will be designed for LIGO searches for continuous gravitational waves, in part by appropriately synthesizing several recent developments in this area. (D) Aspects of general relativity will be tested and demonstrated using LIGO data, including: reconstructing the dispersion relation of gravitational waves, probing the structure of black holes via measuring tidal coupling, detecting the memory effect, and search for general deviations from general relativity, from an ensemble of detected events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was carried out at the California Institute of Technology, in support of the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-wave Observatory.  

In Gravitational-Wave (GW) instrumentation science, this project: (i) Analyzed the quantum mechanics of gravitational-wave detectors in both the TT gauge and the Local Lorenz frame, providing a solid foundation for the Quantum Cramer Rao Bound of GW detector sensitivity, and demonstrating a three-way connection between the detector's quantum-limited sensitivity, its gravitational-wave emissivity, and the decoherence rate of its test masses due to GW emission. (ii) Proposed several strategies toward improving detector sensitivity via quantum parametric amplification, especially in ways that are tolerant to optical losses.

In multi-band GW astronomy, this project studied science cases for next-generation ground-based gravitational wave detectors, systematically explored opportunities that exist in the deci-Hertz frequency band for space-based detectors, and studied event rates  and capabilities of multi-band gravitational-wave detection involving LISA and ground-based detectors. 

In physics of gravitational-wave sources, this project: (i) Explored how to use GW observations to study neutron star physics (via their deformations and possibly oscillations driven by tidal gravity), and proposed strategies for building more accurate waveform templates for compact binaries that contain neutron stars. (ii) Built more accurate and efficient waveform templates for GWs from binary black hole coalescence, as well as highly accurate models that predict final states of such coalescence. (iii) Demonstrated, both theoretically, and using LIGO's data, that "overtones" during the ringdown of the final black hole of a compact binary coalescence can be detected and used to test the "no-hair theorem" of black holes. (iv) Theoretically studied features of "GW echoes" that can follow compact binary coalescence gravitational waves if the final remnant is an exotic compact object instead of a black hole.  

Responding to LIGO's recent detections, this project: (i) Studied the event GW170729 with more accurate waveform models than used by the LIGO-VIRGO collaboration, and provided more reliable esimates of its parameters. (ii) Explored the possiblity that events like GW190521 can be the result of three-body interactions.  

By applying principles of quantum physics to experiments in gravitational physics, this project served as a bridge between the gravitational physics and the quantum physics communities. Visualizations build by this project was used widely as education materials for the general public. This project provided the opportunity for 9 graduate students and 2 postdoctoral scholars to receive training in research.
